description: Belgium is taking anti-disinformation measures from 21st of April. UNESCO Brussels, the European Union and Twitter join forces to launch a European social media campaign to address misinformation on Covid-19 and #ThinkBeforeSharing.

description: On the 27th of May the consultation committee has announced a gradual return to school in Belgium. All lessons in preschools will be able to resume from 2 June. All lessons in primary schools will be able to resume from 8 June (possibly with a 'trial' day on 5 June). As far as secondary education is concerned, the Communities may decide to allow more pupils to return to school but only for a few days.

description: Belgium: Authorities in Antwerp announced on Monday, July 27, that a 23:30 to 06:00. The new measures will come into effect on July 29 and are set to be around for at least four weeks.

Belgium: Authorities in Antwerp announced on Monday, July 27, that a 23:30 to 06:00 curfew will be imposed in the province of Antwerp. The new measures will come into effect on July 29 and are set to last for at least four weeks.

Belgium: Authorities in Antwerp announced on Monday, July 27, that a 23:30 to 06:00 curfew will be imposed in the province of Antwerp. The new measures will come into effect on July 29 and are set to last for at least four weeks. 
Authorities in Antwerp have suspended the city's 23:30-06:00 curfew from Aug. 7, for the duration of an ongoing heatwave.

Belgium: On 12 August Antwerp Governor Cathy Berx announced that the late-night curfew imposed in late July will be shortened by three hours, with residents required to be indoors from 1:30 AM to 5:00 AM.
Belgium: On 26 August the governor of Antwerp announced that the curfew in the province of 1:30 AM to 5:00 AM will not be renewed after it expires on the night of 26 August.

In Belgium as of June 15th, Belgium will open its borders for travel to and from the European Union, including the United Kingdom and the four other Schengen countries (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Iceland and Norway). However, it is up to each country to decide whether to open its borders. To know the situation in the country of destination, it is therefore advisable to consult the website of the FPS Foreign Affairs. The conditions for travel outside of Europe have yet to be defined in light of the evolution of discussions at European level.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
May 4th: Belgium will introduce a new contact tracing strategy, from 11 May onward. The strategy looks as follows:

When a patient is tested, the doctor performing the test will ask the patient to record their contacts over the last few days.

From the middle of this week, patients infected with Covid-19 will be contacted by a call centre to ask who they have been in close contact with over the past few days. The form they filled out may be helpful during this call. People who have recently been in close contact with an infected person will also be called by the call centre. Their state of health will be assessed and, on that basis, they will be asked to take the necessary measures.

The infected patients’ general practitioner will already ask them whether they have been in close contact with certain people, such as people living in the same household. In this case, the general practitioner can issue a quarantine certificate for these people, even if the individuals concerned do not (yet) show symptoms and are fit for work. Individuals who have been issued with such a quarantine certificate must comply with the isolation measures. They can, however, work from home.

Under certain, strictly defined conditions this quarantine certificate may also be issued by the call centre under the responsibility of a hygiene inspector.
In Belgium, as of June 8th it will be possible to travel within Belgium for trips lasting one or more days.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: Belgium announced that a national lockdown will go into effect on March 18th until April 5.

Belgium announced that a national lockdown will go into effect on March 18th until April 5. 
UPDATE: On March 27th, the Belgian National Security Council announced that the lockdown will be extended until April 19th with stricter enforcement of lockdown policies.
UPDATE: Belgium will be in lockdown until May 4th when it will start its 3 phase plan

Belgium announced that a national lockdown will go into effect on March 18th until April 5. 
UPDATE: On March 27th, the Belgian National Security Council announced that the lockdown will be extended until April 19th with stricter enforcement of lockdown policies.

April 15th: Previously, no visitors were in allowed in Belgian nursing homes. From May 3rd onward, however, residents of residential facilities – i.e. rest and care homes or centres for people with disabilities – will be allowed to be visited by a pre-designated person. 
The condition is that the person in question has not shown any symptoms of the disease in the past two weeks. It must always be the same person. The residential facilities will be able to organise these visits themselves. These rules will also apply to people who live in isolation and are unable to move around.

It is unclear when this policy is slated to end.
Belgium created a new police task force responsible for enforcing lockdown in a unified manner towards civilians and businesses
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: May 6th Belgium relaxes the restrictions on gatherings From May 10th onward the regulations look as follows Every family may receive a maximum of four people  always the same  at home To limit the number of contacts and to prevent the spread of the virus visitors can only meet with one family The aim is to minimize the number of families people under the same roof meeting each other and to ensure the greatest level of reciprocityThis is possible under the following conditions A safe distance must of course be observed with the visitors If people have an outside garden or terrace it is better to organize this visit outside Clearly no visitors are allowed if a family member or one of the visitors is ill Special attention should be paid to older and vulnerable peopleIt is unclear when this policy is slated to end

description:
May 13th: Belgium has relaxed the closure of non-essential businesses as part of exit strategy phase 2. Yet, bars and cafes must still remain closed.
It is not clear when they can open again.

May 13th: Belgium has relaxed the closure of non-essential businesses as part of exit strategy phase 2. Yet, bars and cafes must still remain closed.
It is not clear when they can open again.

May 6th: Previously, all non-essential businesses in Belgium had to close their doors. Since May 11th, all regular stores can open again (at earlier stages, fabric stores, garden centres and DIY stores were allowed to open already).

Yet, many non-essential businesses must remain closed still. These include:
- Markets (only individual market stalls (food and non-food) will be allowed by the local authorities and at the usual locations)
- Cafes, bars, restaurants and festivity halls
- Recreational, cultural and tourist sites 
- Hairdressers, beautycians and other businesses that require physical contact

description:
May 6th: Previously, all non-essential businesses in Belgium had to close their doors. Since May 11th, all regular stores can open again (at earlier stages, fabric stores, garden centres and DIY stores were allowed to open already).

On May 13th Belgium announces that certain non-essential businesses to open their door again. These are "professions requiring close contact with customers" (e.g. beautycians) as well as markets and nature attractions like zoos.
These policy relaxations are part of Belgium's exit strategy, phase 2 and will take effect on May 18th.

The non-essential businesses must remain closed include:
- Cafes, bars, restaurants and festivity halls

description:
12th of March: Belgium encourages citizens to work from home.
The instructions are as follows:
Keep working, but work from home as much as possible. Postpone meetings or organise them online. When at work, keep a distance from each other and follow the hygiene prescriptions. If possible, change working hours so that less people are at work at the same time.
Teleworking/working from home will be prolonged until April 19th.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
15th of April: Belgium encourages citizens to work from home.
The instructions are as follows:
Keep working, but work from home as much as possible. Postpone meetings or organise them online. When at work, keep a distance from each other and follow the hygiene prescriptions. If possible, change working hours so that less people are at work at the same time.

This advice is set to last until May 3rd.
April 24th Belgium allows the exrcise of sports that do not require physical contact in open air from May 4th onward The policy applies to the entire country
18th of March Belgium places a ban on all gatherings until April 5th at least

type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description:
In Belgium as of June 8th 2020, sporting events (organized and supervised by a person in charge) are limited to 20 people in June and 50 people in July, subject to safety distances.

From 8 June, non-contact sports activities can be resumed, both indoor and outdoor, amateur or professional, league and training. Gyms and fitness rooms may also be reopened, subject to protocol.

However:

    Contact sports (e.g. judo, boxing, football, etc.) should always be limited to “contactless” training;
    As far as sports facilities are concerned, the protocols will also have to be followed. Changing rooms and showers will still not be accessible;
    Swimming pools, saunas and wellness centres have to remain closed at this stage.

As far as sports are concerned, everything will be allowed again from 1 July, provided that the protocols are respected.

In both the cultural and sports industries, from 1 July, a seated audience of up to 200 people - regardless of the size of the venue - will be allowed, subject to safety distances and always in strict compliance with protocols.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description:
In Belgium as of June 8th, leisure and free-time activities will be permitted.

Cultural and leisure activities have to be organised in such a way as to avoid large gatherings. Wearing a mask is recommended at all times. Gatherings (e.g. village fairs, village festivals, etc.) are prohibited until 1 August and may then be resumed gradually. Large-scale mass events, on the other hand, will remain prohibited until 31 August, as previously announced.

In Belgium from 8 June, cultural activities may resume without an audience present.  Performances with an audience - including cinemas - can be resumed from 1 July, but only subject to specific rules regarding crowd management, such as respecting the safety distance in the audience and a maximum of 200 attendees.

Activities should be organised in such a way as to avoid gatherings of too many people, e.g. outside the venue.  When people take part in cultural and leisure activities, wearing a mask is recommended at all times.  Cultural events would be limited to 20 people in June and 50 people in July, subject to safety restritions.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
